events.event: On 3 November 2010 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg held that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been unlawful and had to be set aside.
events.event_who: Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg
events.event_what: held that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been unlawful

events.event: On 25 January 2011 the St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 3 November 2010 and dismissed the first applicant’s complaint against the decision of the FMS of 25 January 2010.
events.event_what: quashed the decision of 3 November 2010 and dismissed the first applicant’s complaint against the decision of the FMS of 25 January 2010

events.event: In 2011 the FMS brought court proceedings against the applicants, seeking their eviction from the room.
events.event_what: brought court proceedings against the applicants

events.event: The local authorities objected to the eviction, because the room was the only dwelling available to the second applicant.
The applicants submitted that their eviction would be in breach of Article 8 of the Convention, since it was not necessary in a democratic society.
events.event_what: submitted that their eviction would be in breach

events.event: On 15 May 2012 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg ordered the applicants’ eviction from their room, without providing any alternative accommodation.
events.event_who: Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg
events.event_what: ordered the applicants’ eviction from their room

events.event: The applicants lodged an appeal against the eviction order, submitting that their eviction was disproportionate since the court had not taken their arguments into account.
events.event_what: lodged an appeal against the eviction order

events.event: On 4 October 2012 the St Petersburg City Court upheld the eviction order.
The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal against the above decisions.
events.event_what: did not lodge a cassation appeal

events.event: On 22 November 2012 the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings with regard to the eviction order.
events.event_what: instituted enforcement proceedings with regard to the eviction order

events.event: On 13 May 2013 the first applicant asked the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg to provide her with alternative accommodation.
events.event_what: asked the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg to provide her with alternative accommodation

events.event: On 12 August 2013 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg concluded an agreement with the first applicant for use of social accommodation free of charge for a period of one year.
events.event_who: administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg
events.event_what: concluded an agreement with the first applicant for use of social accommodation

events.event: On 12 September 2013 the applicants vacated the disputed room in compliance with the eviction order of 15 May 2012.
On 11 March 2015 the enforcement proceedings were terminated on the grounds that the applicants had voluntarily vacated the room.
Since 15 March 2016 the second applicant has been registered as living in the flat belonging to his father and his paternal grandmother.
events.event_what: has been registered as living in the flat
Declares the complaint concerning the applicants’ right to respect of their home admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 9348/14) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Andrey Igorevich Resin (“the applicant”), on 17 December 2013.
From 25 May 2012 to 10 April 2014 the applicant was held in penal colony IK-56 in the Sverdlovsk Region.
He was able to have five short visits in 2013 and one short visit in 2014.
events.event_what: was able to have five short visits

events.event: On 15 July 2013 the applicant asked the governor to allow him a short meeting with four adult relatives, his mother, sister and two cousins.
events.event_what: asked the governor to allow him a short meeting

events.event: He also asked for the meeting to be held without a glass partition between him and his visitors or the presence of a prison officer.
events.event_what: asked for the meeting to be held without a glass partition

events.event: The governor signed his decision on the petition: “Rejected. Not allowed under the Code of Execution of Sentences”.
events.event_what: signed his decision on the petition: “Rejected.

events.event: From 15 May to 16 July 2014 the applicant was transferred to remand prison SIZO-1 in Khabarovsk – where his family still lived – to take part in another investigation.

On the day after his arrival at the prison, he asked the prison governor to authorise a short meeting with four family members – his sister, two cousins and aunt – without a physical partition between him and the visitors or the presence of prison officers.
events.event_when: the day after his arrival at the prison
events.event_what: asked the prison governor to authorise a short meeting

events.event: By a letter of 21 May 2014, the governor rejected his request.
On 3 June 2014 the applicant asked the governor to authorise a long meeting with his mother and sister.
events.event_what: asked the governor to authorise a long meeting

events.event: Three days later the governor replied that the applicable law did not make a provision for long-stay visits in respect of remand prisoners.
events.event_what: replied that the applicable law did not make a provision for long-stay visits

events.event: The applicant subsequently asked the authorities in charge of the criminal case to authorise short visits from his family members.
events.event_what: asked the authorities in charge of the criminal case to authorise short visits

events.event: On 11 June and 1 August 2014 the investigator and the deputy head of the investigations department, respectively, rejected his request.
events.event_who: investigator and the deputy head of the investigations department

events.event: The applicant challenged the restrictions on family visits before a court of general jurisdiction.
events.event_what: challenged the restrictions on family visits before a court

events.event: According to a certificate issued by the governor on 27 April 2017, the applicant did not have any short or long-stay visits during his time in the Khabarovsk remand prison.
events.event_when: during his time in the Khabarovsk remand prison

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 11467/15) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Ms S.N. (“the applicant”), on 20 February 2015.

On 26 June 2012 Mr N. reported to the inter-district investigative committee that, since 2010, his minor daughter, the applicant in the present case, had been repeatedly forced to have oral and anal sex with eleven men over a period of almost two years from October or September 2010 to June 2012.
events.event_what: his minor daughter, the applicant in the present case, had been repeatedly forced to have oral and anal sex

events.event: In response to a complaint lodged by the applicant’s father, the authorities instituted a preliminary inquiry during which P., an investigator, questioned the applicant (who provided a detailed account of the above-mentioned events), subjected the applicant to a gynaecological examination (which did not detect any traces of sexual assault on the applicant’s body), conducted an inspection of the locations where the alleged rapes had taken place and collected wet towel wipes found at the location of the “T.L.” area (the applicant having explained that one of the rapists had wiped himself with a towel wipe).
On 18 July 2012 the applicant’s lawyer submitted a DVD with a video recording of one of the alleged occasions.
events.event_what: submitted a DVD with a video recording

events.event: On 20 July 2012 the investigator examined the video recording.

Having examined the material obtained in the course of the inquiry, P., the investigator, discerned no evidence to support the applicant’s allegations of rape and on 26 July 2012 issued a decision declining to open a criminal investigation against the alleged perpetrators.
events.event_what: issued a decision declining to open a criminal investigation

events.event: On 2 August 2012 the head of the inter-district investigative committee quashed the decision of 26 July 2012, noting that the investigator had not questioned all the alleged perpetrators and had failed to obtain the results of the forensic examination.
events.event_who: head of the inter-district investigative committee

events.event: On 12 August 2012 P. declined to open a criminal investigation.
events.event_what: declined to open a criminal investigation

events.event: On 17 August 2012 the deputy head of the investigative committee quashed the decision of 12 August 2012, noting that the investigator had failed to comply with the decision of 2 August 2012.
events.event_who: deputy head of the investigative committee

events.event: On 27 August 2012 P. issued a decision declining to open a criminal investigation.
events.event_what: issued a decision declining to open a criminal investigation

events.event: The said decision was quashed by the deputy head of the investigative committee on 4 October 2012.
On 3 November 2012 P., the investigator, declined to open a criminal investigation.
events.event_what: declined to open a criminal investigation

events.event: On 28 November 2012 the head of the investigative committee opened a criminal investigation into the applicant’s allegations of rape.
On 15 January 2013 the applicant was granted the status of victim of a crime and advised of her procedural rights.
events.event_what: was granted the status of victim

events.event: On several occasions the investigator questioned the alleged perpetrators.
On 10 and 11 March 2013 M.G., Dzh.A., K.G., Dzh.N., Sh.D., M.M., N.A., and M.Kh. were arrested and remanded in custody on the charges of rape.
events.event_who: M.G., Dzh.A., K.G., Dzh.N., Sh.D., M.M., N.A., and M.Kh.
events.event_what: were arrested and remanded in custody

events.event: On 13 and 19 March 2013 they were released.

On 17 June 2013 the forensic expert prepared a report concerning the examination of the flash memory drives of six mobile telephones which the investigator had earlier obtained from the alleged perpetrators. The expert indicated that it was impossible to restore the flash memory drives of the phones because the laboratory did not have the necessary equipment.
events.event_what: indicated that it was impossible to restore the flash memory drives of the phones

events.event: On 9 August 2013 the forensic expert concluded that the genetic material collected at the location indicated by the applicant could not have originated from Dzh.A., K.G. or Dzh.N.
events.event_what: concluded that the genetic material collected at the location indicated by the applicant could not have originated from Dzh.A., K.G. or Dzh.N.

events.event: On 4 October 2013 an investigator, Z., ordered that the applicant undergo a polygraph test.
events.event_what: ordered that the applicant undergo a polygraph test

events.event: On 7 October 2013 the applicant underwent the test.
On 9 October M.G. underwent a polygraph testing.
On 6 December 2013 D., an investigator, suspended the investigation.

On 13 January 2014 the first deputy head of the republican investigative committee determined that the criminal investigation had been incomplete and perfunctory and quashed the decision of 6 December 2013, ordering a further investigation.
events.event_who: first deputy head of the republican investigative committee

events.event: On 25 February 2014 D. discontinued the criminal investigation, noting that there was no evidence, except for the applicant’s statements, implicating seven of the alleged perpetrators.
On 16 May 2014 D. discontinued, on similar grounds, the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P.
events.event_what: discontinued, on similar grounds, the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P.

events.event: On 20 June 2014 the Sovetskiy District Court dismissed a complaint lodged by the applicant against the decision of 25 February 2014.
events.event_what: dismissed a complaint lodged by the applicant

events.event: On 20 August 2014 the Supreme Court upheld the said decision on appeal.
events.event_what: upheld the said decision on appeal

events.event: On 28 January 2015 the deputy head of the second division of the republican investigative committee quashed the decision of 16 May 2015 and reopened the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P.
events.event_who: deputy head of the second division of the republican investigative committee
events.event_what: reopened the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P.

events.event: On the same date he discontinued the criminal investigation.
On 29 January 2015 the District Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint against the decision of 16 May 2014.
On 1 April 2015 the Supreme Court of the Dagestan Republic upheld the decision of 29 January 2015 on appeal.
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Dagestan Republic

events.event: On 1 September 2015 the District Court quashed the decision of 29 January 2015.
On 30 September 2015 the Presidium of the Supreme Court quashed the decisions of 20 June 2014 and 20 August 2014.
On 2 October 2015 the investigative committee reopened the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P.
events.event_what: reopened the criminal investigation against M.G. and A.P

events.event: On the same date the investigative committee discontinued the criminal investigation.
On 27 October 2015 the District Court accepted the applicant’s argument that the investigation had been incomplete and found the decision of 25 February 2014 to have been unlawful.
After the reopening of the case, the investigator questioned Dzh.A., K.G., Dzh.N. and Sh.D.
events.event_when: After the reopening of the case
events.event_what: questioned Dzh.A., K.G., Dzh.N. and Sh.D.

events.event: On 30 January 2016 the criminal investigation was discontinued.
On 18 November 2016 the Government were requested to submit a complete investigation file in the applicant’s case.
events.event_what: were requested to submit a complete investigation file

events.event: On 29 March 2017 the Government submitted an incomplete copy of the material from the case file (comprising 898 pages, including seventeen pages containing nine tables of contents).
events.event_what: submitted an incomplete copy of the material from the case file

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 55216/08) against the Italian Republic lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by an Italian national, Ms S.V. (“the applicant”), on 13 November 2008.
At birth, the applicant was entered in the civil-status registers as male and was given the forename L.
events.event_what: was entered in the civil-status registers as male

events.event: However, the applicant stated that she had always identified as female and lived in society as a woman under the forename S.
events.event_what: stated that she had always identified as female

events.event: In 1999 S.V. began treatment with feminising hormones as part of the gender transition process.

On 9 November 2000 she applied to the Rome District Court on the basis of section 3 of Law no. 164 of 1982, stating that she wished to complete the transition process by permanently changing her primary sexual characteristics, and sought authorisation to undergo gender reassignment surgery.
events.event_what: applied to the Rome District Court

events.event: In a judgment of 10 May 2001 the District Court found that the applicant had embarked on the gender transition process after careful consideration.
events.event_what: found that the applicant had embarked on the gender transition process

events.event: Having taken note of her determination the court authorised her to undergo surgery in order to adapt her primary sexual characteristics to match her female gender identity.

On 30 May 2001 the applicant, while awaiting the surgery authorised by the District Court, applied to the prefect of Rome for a change of forename under Article 89 of Presidential Decree no. 396 of 2000.
events.event_what: applied to the prefect of Rome for a change of forename

events.event: In a decision of 4 July 2001 the prefect refused the applicant’s request on the grounds that, under Presidential Decree no. 396 of 2000, a person’s forename had to correspond to his or her gender.
The applicant appealed against that decision to the Lazio Regional Administrative Court and also requested a stay of execution of the prefect’s decision.
On 23 July 2001 the applicant underwent mammoplasty.
On 6 September 2001 she was placed on a waiting list at Trieste University Hospital for surgery to alter her primary sexual characteristics.
events.event_what: was placed on a waiting list

events.event: On 21 February 2002 the Regional Administrative Court refused to grant a stay of execution of the prefect’s decision.
events.event_what: refused to grant a stay of execution of the prefect’s decision

events.event: On 3 February 2003, while the proceedings before the Regional Administrative Court were still pending on the merits, the applicant underwent an operation to change her sexual characteristics from male to female.
events.event_what: underwent an operation to change her sexual characteristics

events.event: She subsequently applied to the Rome District Court, on an unspecified date, for legal recognition of her gender reassignment under section 3 of Law no. 164 of 1982.
events.event_what: applied to the Rome District Court

events.event: In a judgment of 10 October 2003 the Rome District Court granted the applicant’s request and ordered the Savona municipal authorities to alter the indication of the applicant’s gender from male to female and to change the forename L. to S.
By a judgment of 6 March 2008, deposited with the registry on 17 May 2008, the Regional Administrative Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the prefect’s decision of 4 July 2001.
events.event_what: dismissed the applicant’s appeal against the prefect’s decision

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 69820/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by two Russian nationals, Ms Natalya Yevgenyevna Shvidkaya (“the first applicant”) and Ms Yelizaveta Alekseyevna Shvidkaya (“the second applicant”), on 4 November 2010.
In the beginning of 2002 they moved to Moscow and decided to purchase a flat there.
events.event_what: moved to Moscow and decided to purchase a flat there

events.event: On 16 October 2002 the Housing Department of the City of Moscow signed a social tenancy agreement with a certain K. in respect of a two-room flat at 32-70-69, Prospekt Vernadskogo, Moscow.
events.event_who: Housing Department of the City of Moscow
events.event_what: signed a social tenancy agreement with a certain K.

events.event: In October 2002 the first applicant bought a flat in Kaluga Region with the intention of exchanging it for a flat in Moscow.
events.event_what: bought a flat in Kaluga Region

events.event: On 23 October 2002 K. applied to Moszhilservice (the Moscow State commercial agency) for authorisation to exchange his flat in Moscow, occupied under a social tenancy agreement, for the flat in Kaluga Region belonging to the first applicant.
On 29 October 2002 the Committee for Exchange of Housing authorised the exchange of flats between K. and the first applicant.
events.event_what: authorised the exchange of flats between K. and the first applicant

events.event: On 6 November 2002 the first applicant received an exchange voucher authorising her to move into the flat in Moscow.
events.event_what: received an exchange voucher authorising her to move into the flat in Moscow

events.event: Later in November 2002 the applicants were registered as living in that flat. The applicants paid a sum of money to B.
events.event_what: were registered as living in that flat

events.event: In 2004 criminal proceedings were instituted against B. on suspicion of fraud.
events.event_what: were instituted against B. on suspicion of fraud

events.event: On 12 December 2005 the Nikulinskiy District Court, Moscow, (“the District Court”) found B. guilty of fraud. The court established that B. had falsified a court judgment authorising the assignment of the flat at 3270-69, Prospekt Vernadskogo, Moscow to K. under the social tenancy agreement and then fraudulently arranged for the exchange of flats between K. and the first applicant against the payment by the latter of 1,177,773.40 Russian roubles (RUB).
events.event_who: Nikulinskiy District Court, Moscow, (“the District Court”)

events.event: As a result of B.’s criminal actions, the property rights of the City of Moscow to the flat in question had been unlawfully transferred to the first applicant.
events.event_what: had been unlawfully transferred to the first applicant

events.event: On 6 March 2006 the Moscow City Court (“the City Court”) amended the judgment of 12 December 2005.
In October 2008 the Housing Department of the City of Moscow brought court proceedings against the first applicant and K.
events.event_who: Housing Department of the City of Moscow
events.event_what: brought court proceedings against the first applicant and K.

events.event: In April 2009 the first applicant brought a counterclaim against the Housing Department on her own behalf and also on behalf of the second applicant, who was a minor at that time.
events.event_what: brought a counterclaim against the Housing Department

events.event: On 6 October 2009 the District Court invalidated the social tenancy agreement concluded with K., the exchange of the flats between K. and the first applicant and the exchange voucher of 6 November 2002, and ordered the applicants’ eviction.
The first applicant appealed.
On 6 May 2010 the City Court upheld the judgment of 6 October 2009 on appeal.
In 2014 the applicants returned to Blagoveshchensk.
On 9 February 2015 the applicants applied to the Nikulinskiy District Court of Moscow, requesting that a duplicate of the writ of execution in respect of the judgment of 6 October 2009 be issued.
events.event_what: requesting that a duplicate of the writ of execution

events.event: On 21 April 2015 the applicants received the writ of execution.
On 26 June 2015 the bailiff’s office instituted enforcement proceedings in order to recover from K. the amounts awarded in the judgment of 6 October 2009 in favour of the first applicant.
events.event_what: instituted enforcement proceedings in order to recover from K. the amounts awarded
Declares the complaint concerning the applicants’ right to respect for their home admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 35722/15) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Ms Lidiya Pavlovna Sidorova (“the applicant”), on 2 July 2015.

Between 2012 and 2014 the applicant lodged numerous complaints with the local police department concerning the allegedly unauthorised use of the plot of land near the block of flats where her family resided.
On 15 January 2014 the head of the inter-municipal police department forwarded the following letter to the Psychiatric and Narcological Service
events.event_who: head of the inter-municipal police department
events.event_what: forwarded the following letter to the Psychiatric and Narcological Service

events.event: On 28 and 29 January 2014 a psychiatrist, Sav., questioned the applicant’s neighbours, asking them if they had observed any strange behaviour on the applicant’s part.
On 30 January 2014 a psychiatrist visited the applicant at her place of residence.
events.event_what: visited the applicant at her place

events.event: On 31 January 2014 the psychiatrist informed the police that the applicant did not have any psychiatric disorders.
events.event_what: informed the police that the applicant did not have any psychiatric disorders

events.event: On 12 March 2014, in response to the applicant’s complaint, the Dimitrovgrad Town Court found the psychiatrist’s actions unlawful.
On 17 March 2014 the applicant asked the court to find the police’s decision to have her assessed by the psychiatrist unlawful.
events.event_what: asked the court to find the police’s decision to have her assessed by the psychiatrist unlawful

events.event: On 29 April 2014 the Town Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint.
On 22 July 2014 the Ulyanovsk Regional Court upheld the judgment of 29 April 2014 on appeal.
On 17 December 2014 the Regional Court refused to grant the applicant leave to lodge a cassation appeal.
events.event_what: refused to grant the applicant leave to lodge a cassation appeal

events.event: On 26 March 2015 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation issued a similar decision in response to the applicant’s application to lodge a cassation appeal.
events.event_who: Supreme Court of the Russian Federation

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 32074/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Ms Luminiţa Zamfira Solcan (“the applicant”), on 17 April 2014.
The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri.
In 2005 she committed a murder in France.
On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility.

Endorsing the experts’ findings that she posed a danger to the public on account of her mental health, the court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.
events.event_what: ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France

events.event: In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iaşi.
events.event_what: lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania

events.event: By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iaşi.
events.event_what: authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility

events.event: On 11 April 2013 the applicant’s mother died.
On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iaşi District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave.
The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.
By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.

The case originated in an application (no. 66640/12) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Ilie Stana (“the applicant”), on 8 October 2012.

On 20 February 2003 the applicant, a bank manager at that time, was placed in pre-trial detention by the Bucharest Anti-Corruption Department of the Prosecutor’s Office, on a charge of taking a bribe in order to favourably influence the acceptance of a loan requested by M.G.

By a final judgment delivered on 13 April 2012 the High Court of Cassation and Justice (“the High Court”) convicted the applicant of taking a bribe. Among the evidence which led to his conviction was the transcript of a phone conversation between the applicant and M.G. on 16 September 2002.
events.event_who: High Court of Cassation and Justice (“the High Court”)
events.event_what: convicted the applicant of taking a bribe

events.event: The applicant complained before the domestic courts about the lawfulness of the interception of his phone conversation and the accuracy of the transcript.
However, the High Court merely replied that the impugned interception had been lawful and within the scope of Law no. 51/1991.
events.event_what: merely replied that the impugned interception had been lawful

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 70288/13) against the Slovak Republic lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by an Austrian national, Mr Stephan Visy (“the applicant”), on 5 November 2013.

Although no formal charges were brought against him, an investigation into various transactions involving the applicant was carried out in Austria on suspicion of, inter alia , investment fraud, breach of confidence and insider trading.
events.event_what: was carried out in Austria on suspicion of, inter alia , investment fraud, breach of confidence and insider trading

events.event: The search took place in 2009 and business documents and electronic storage media were seized, including from the applicant’s office, and later handed over to the Austrian authorities.

In a judgment of 7 December 2010 the Constitutional Court found that the warrant issued in Slovakia for the search and seizure did not extend to the applicant and his office and that the terms of the warrant had therefore been exceeded, in violation of the applicant’s rights to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions, respect for his private life, and judicial and other legal protection.

On 6 September 2011 the PPS asked the law firm representing the applicant in Slovakia to specify whether they were entitled to receive on his behalf the items that had meanwhile been returned by the Austrian authorities.
On 1 February 2012 the Bratislava I District Police Directorate issued a decision restoring those items to the applicant, identifying them as six specific units of electronic storage media.
events.event_what: issued a decision restoring those items to the applicant

events.event: The applicant claims, and this has not been disputed by the Government, that the media to be returned to the applicant contained, inter alia , legal advice protected by lawyer-client privilege.
On 27 February 2012 the PPS summoned the applicant’s lawyer to its premises on 7 March 2012 with a view to restoring the above-mentioned possessions to the applicant.
On 7 March 2012 at 9.10 a.m. those items were restored to the applicant’s lawyer
at 9.15 a.m., they were all seized from him again with reference to a letter rogatory from the Vienna office of the Prosecution Service of Austria of 14 April 2011.
The applicant lodged a series of requests, complaints and repeated complaints with all levels of the PPS raising two groups of arguments.
All the complaints were dismissed, of which the applicant and his lawyer were ultimately informed by letters of the Office of the Prosecutor General of 10 August and 31 December 2012.

On 11 March 2013 the applicant lodged a fresh complaint under Article 127 of the Constitution, arguing that by failing to ensure full compliance with the Constitutional Court’s judgment of 7 December 2010 and seizing the restored items again, the Slovakian authorities had been responsible for a violation of a number of his rights, including respect for his private life and correspondence and the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions and of failing to provide an effective remedy.
On 16 May 2013 the Constitutional Court declared the complaint inadmissible.

The case originated in an application (no. 15978/09) against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Ukrainian national, Mr Igor Viktorovych Yakushev (“the applicant”), on 7 March 2009.
On 17 November 1993 M. gave birth to a baby girl, K.
events.event_what: gave birth to a baby girl, K.

events.event: Given that the applicant had had relations with M. at the relevant time, on 2 December 1993 he accepted paternity of K. by submitting the relevant declaration to the authorities.
events.event_what: accepted paternity of K. by submitting the relevant declaration to the authorities

events.event: On 23 March 2000 the applicant married M.
They divorced in 2006.
In July 2006 the applicant instituted proceedings in the Malyn District Court against M., challenging the paternity of K.
On 24 March 2008 the District Court found for the applicant, relying on a genetic expert’s opinion which excluded the possibility of the applicant being K.’s biological father.
events.event_what: excluded the possibility of the applicant being K.’s biological father

events.event: M. appealed, stating that from January 1993 she and the applicant had lived together without being married and that she had never had any doubts about the applicant’s paternity of K.

On 29 May 2008 the Zhytomyr Regional Court of Appeal quashed the first-instance court’s decision and held that, under Article 56 of the Family and Marriage Code, the applicant had not had a right to challenge his paternity because at the time that he accepted paternity of K., he was aware that he was not K.’s father.

The applicant appealed on a point of law, contending that there were no grounds for the Court of Appeal to find that at the material time he was aware that he was not the biological father of the child.
On 9 September 2008 the Supreme Court of Ukraine rejected the appeal by the applicant as unfounded.
events.event_what: rejected the appeal by the applicant as unfounded

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 35237/14) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Belarussian national, Mr Valentina Dmitriyevna Yermakovich (“the applicant”), on 12 March 2015.
On 1 August 2000 the Ministry of the Interior of Belarus ordered the applicant’s arrest on suspicion of her having committed several criminal offences.
events.event_who: Ministry of the Interior of Belarus

events.event: On an unspecified date her name was put on the international wanted persons list.
events.event_what: was put on the international wanted persons list

events.event: On 18 February 2014 the applicant was arrested in Lyubertsy, Moscow Region.
On 20 February 2014 the Lyubertsy Town Court of the Moscow Region authorised the applicant’s detention for forty days pending her extradition to Belarus.
events.event_who: Lyubertsy Town Court of the Moscow Region

events.event: On 28 March 2014 the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention until 18 August 2014.
On 18 August 2014 the Town Court extended the applicant’s detention until 18 February 2015.
On 18 September 2014 the Moscow Regional Court upheld the decision of 18 August 2014 on appeal.
On 10 February 2015 the Town Prosecutor ordered the applicant’s release on an undertaking not to leave town.
On 20 August and 21 September 2015 the investigative committee of the Republic of Belarus discontinued the criminal proceedings against the applicant.
events.event_who: investigative committee of the Republic of Belarus

events.event: On 4 February 2016 the Town Prosecutor discontinued the extradition proceedings against the applicant.
From 21 February 2014 to 10 February 2015 the applicant was detained in remand prison SIZO-6 in the Moscow Region.
On 26 February 2014 the Deputy Town Prosecutor carried out an inspection of remand prison SIZO-6.
events.event_what: carried out an inspection of remand prison

events.event: On an unspecified date in 2014 the Regional Prosecutor’s Office carried out an inspection of the conditions of detention in remand prison SIZO-6.
events.event_what: carried out an inspection of the conditions of detention

events.event: On 21 March 2014 the Regional Prosecutor issued a notice to the head of the regional penal service (FSIN), advising that the conditions of detention in the prison be brought in line with the statutory requirements.
According to the applicant, between February and March 2014 the Town Prosecutor authorised the applicant’s mother to visit her at the remand prison on three occasions.
events.event_what: authorised the applicant’s mother to visit her

events.event: On 10 October 2014, in response to a request by the applicant to meet with her family, the Prosecutor General’s Office responded that, as stipulated in the Pre-trial Detention Act, suspects and defendants could have no more than two family visits per month, subject to written authorisation from the official or authority in charge of the criminal case, and advised the applicant to apply to the law-enforcement bodies in Belarus for approval of her relatives’ visits.
On 21 January 2015 the Tverskoy District Court of Moscow dismissed a complaint by the applicant against the prosecutor’s decision of 10 October 2014, without considering the merits.
On 11 March 2015 the Moscow City Court quashed the decision of 21 January 2015 and remitted the matter to the District Court for fresh consideration.
On 6 May 2015 the District Court dismissed the applicant’s complaint against the decision of 10 October 2014.
On 17 August 2015 the City Court upheld the decision of 6 May 2015 on appeal.
On 24 January 2001 the applicant was issued with a Russian passport by the Russian Embassy in Minsk, Belarus.
events.event_what: was issued with a Russian passport

events.event: On an unspecified date she moved to Moscow, Russia.
On 20 August 2004 a district police department in Moscow issued an internal passport in the applicant’s name.
On 16 February 2012 the Moscow City Department of the Federal Migration Service decided, on the basis of an earlier inquiry, that the applicant had been wrongly issued with a Russian passport.
events.event_who: Moscow City Department of the Federal Migration Service

events.event: On 5 February 2015 the Lyublinskiy District Court of Moscow dismissed a complaint by the applicant against the decision of 16 February 2012.
On 26 June 2015 the City Court upheld the decision of 5 February 2015.
On an unspecified date the applicant, being a Belorussian citizen, applied for a residency permit in Russia.
events.event_what: applied for a residency permit in Russia

events.event: On 17 April 2017 the Federal Migration Service issued a residency permit.

events.event_what: Declares the complaints concerning the conditions of the applicant’s detention, alleged lack of review of her detention, and lack of family visits admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible

events.event: The case originated in an application (no. 66610/10) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Russian national, Mr Yevgeniy Nikolayevich Zakharov (“the applicant”) on 16 October 2010.
Until 1999 the applicant was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.’s parents.
events.event_what: was married to Z. and was living with her in a state-owned flat which had been provided to Z.’s parents

events.event: The applicant was registered as living in that flat.
events.event_what: was registered as living in that flat

events.event: In 1999 the applicant and Z. divorced and the applicant moved in with his new partner, B.
At that time he did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife.
events.event_what: did not apply for deregistration from the flat which he had occupied with his former wife

events.event: Later Z. privatised that flat, and the applicant lost occupational right to it.
They never married and the applicant was not registered as living in the room.
events.event_what: was not registered as living in the room

events.event: In May 2009 B. died and her neighbours locked the applicant out of the flat.
The local housing authority informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room, since he had no legal right to occupy it.
events.event_what: informed the applicant that he had to vacate the room

events.event: On 28 September 2009 the applicant instituted court proceedings against the local administration, seeking recognition of his right to occupy the room as B.’s family member.

The local administration submitted that the applicant had not been registered as living in B.’s room, he was not a member of B.’s family and, therefore, he had not acquired any right to occupy her room.
events.event_what: submitted that the applicant had not been registered as living in B.’s room, he was not a member of B.’s family

events.event: On 6 May 2010 the Leninskiy District Court (“the District Court”) of Kaliningrad granted the applicant’s claim with reference to Articles 69 and 70 of the Housing Code (see Relevant domestic law and practice below).
events.event_who: Leninskiy District Court (“the District Court”) of Kaliningrad

events.event: The local administration did not appeal against the judgment of 6 May 2010.
The third parties appealed against that judgment to the Kaliningrad Regional Court (“the Regional Court”).
On 22 September 2010 the Regional Court quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims.
events.event_what: quashed the judgment of 6 May 2010 and dismissed the applicant’s claims

events.event: On 3 March 2011 a judge of the Supreme Court of Russia (“the Supreme Court”) refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision of 22 September 2010 to the Civil Chamber of the Supreme Court for examination, finding no grounds for such review and relying on the principle of legal certainty.
events.event_who: judge of the Supreme Court of Russia (“the Supreme Court”)
events.event_what: refused to refer the applicant’s application for supervisory review of the decision
